<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 326, 294]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 154, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 278, 905, 333]]<|/det|>
0606/12 February/March 2019 2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 437, 374]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Electronic calculator  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 406]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 431]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 431, 320, 445]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 445, 504, 460]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 460, 504, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 475, 384, 490]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 282, 515]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 515, 828, 545]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 545, 599, 560]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 559, 604, 574]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 585, 604, 600]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 600, 759, 615]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 615, 440, 629]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 80.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 599, 91]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 165, 561, 183]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 196, 240, 214]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 226, 383, 245]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2} + b x + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 243, 572, 284]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 313, 228, 330]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 333, 754, 375]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n},\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 381, 494, 418]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 481, 594, 500]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 514, 156, 530]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 542, 581, 610]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 640, 242, 658]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 664, 591, 698]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 717, 593, 771]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\] \[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 74, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
On the axes below, sketch the graph of the curve \(y = \left|2x^{2} - 5x - 3\right|\), stating the coordinates of any points where the curve meets the coordinate axes.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 166, 920, 470]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 475, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 87, 94, 106]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 85, 143, 106]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 78, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the first 3 terms in the expansion, in ascending powers of \(x\), of \(\left(3 - \frac{x}{9}\right)^6\). Give the terms in their simplest form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 415, 143, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 405, 715, 440]]<|/det|>
Hence find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(3 - \frac{x}{9}\right)^6 \left(x - \frac{2}{x}\right)^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 414, 920, 433]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 2x^{3} + ax^{2} + bx - 49\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants. When \(\mathrm{p}'(x)\) is divided by \(x + 3\) there is a remainder of \(-24\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 121, 144, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 121, 336, 140]]<|/det|>
Show that \(6a - b = 78\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 255, 445, 274]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(2x - 1\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 286, 143, 305]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 286, 369, 305]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a\) and of \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 286, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 559, 141, 577]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 559, 675, 577]]<|/det|>
Write \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) in the form \((2x - 1)\mathrm{Q}(x)\), where \(\mathrm{Q}(x)\) is a quadratic factor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 559, 920, 577]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 810, 141, 828]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 810, 403, 828]]<|/det|>
Hence factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) completely.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 810, 920, 828]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 764, 92]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\log_{4}x = p\). Giving your answer in its simplest form, find, in terms of \(p\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 143, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 103, 267, 122]]<|/det|>
\(\log_{4}(16x)\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 280, 143, 299]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 268, 275, 311]]<|/det|>
\(\log_{4}\left(\frac{x^{7}}{256}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 280, 920, 299]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 458, 420, 477]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to parts (i) and (ii),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 485, 141, 505]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 476, 781, 510]]<|/det|>
solve \(\log_{4}(16x) - \log_{4}\left(\frac{x^{7}}{256}\right) = 5\), giving your answer correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 488, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 92, 97, 112]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 144, 109]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 78, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & - 4 \\ 0 & - 1 \end{pmatrix}, \mathbf{B} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & - 4 \\ 2 & 5 \\ 3 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\) and \(\mathbf{C} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & - 2 & 0 \end{pmatrix}\), write down the matrix products which are possible. You do not need to evaluate your products.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 127, 920, 146]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 299, 144, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 288, 520, 325]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathbf{X} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & - 2 \\ 5 & 3 \end{pmatrix}\) and \(\mathbf{Y} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 1 \\ 2 & 0 \end{pmatrix}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 345, 181, 364]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 344, 277, 364]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathbf{X}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 345, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 556, 180, 575]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 555, 520, 576]]<|/det|>
Hence find the matrix \(\mathbf{Z}\) such that \(\mathbf{XZ} = \mathbf{Y}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 556, 920, 575]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 432, 88]]<|/det|>
Do not use a calculator in this question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 462, 120]]<|/det|>
All lengths in this question are in centimetres.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 133, 752, 305]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 325, 920, 359]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the trapezium \(ABCD\), where \(AB = 2 + 3\sqrt{5}\), \(DC = 6 + 3\sqrt{5}\), \(AD = 10 - 2\sqrt{5}\) and angle \(ADC = 90^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 373, 143, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 373, 845, 392]]<|/det|>
Find the area of \(ABCD\), giving your answer in the form \(a + b\sqrt{5}\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 612, 141, 629]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 612, 920, 644]]<|/det|>
Find \(\cot BCD\), giving your answer in the form \(c + d\sqrt{5}\), where \(c\) and \(d\) are fractions in their simplest form. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 102, 907, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 448, 920, 485]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the velocity-time graph of a particle \(P\) moving in a straight line with velocity \(\nu \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) at time \(t\) seconds after leaving a fixed point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 497, 143, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 497, 591, 515]]<|/det|>
Write down the value of the acceleration of \(P\) when \(t = 5\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 497, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 613, 143, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 677, 631]]<|/det|>
Find the distance travelled by the particle \(P\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 10\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 613, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A particle \(Q\) moves such that its velocity, \(v \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\), \(t\) seconds after leaving a fixed point, is given by \(\nu = 3 \sin 2t - 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 180, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 116, 452, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of \(Q\) when \(t = \frac{7\pi}{12}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 358, 181, 376]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 356, 667, 377]]<|/det|>
Find the least value of \(t\) for which the acceleration of \(Q\) is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 357, 920, 376]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 531, 90]]<|/det|>
The area of a sector of a circle of radius \(r \text{cm}\) is \(36 \text{cm}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 144, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 100, 675, 121]]<|/det|>
Show that the perimeter, \(P \text{cm}\), of the sector is such that \(P = 2r + \frac{72}{r}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 393, 143, 412]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 393, 784, 413]]<|/det|>
Hence, given that \(r\) can vary, find the stationary value of \(P\) and determine its nature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 394, 920, 413]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 104, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 77, 816, 104]]<|/det|>
A curve is such that when \(x = 0\), both \(y = - 5\) and \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = 10\). Given that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^2y}{\mathrm{dx}^2} = 4\mathrm{e}^{2x} + 3\), find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 114, 143, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 114, 348, 133]]<|/det|>
the equation of the curve,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 114, 920, 133]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 631, 143, 650]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 625, 641, 650]]<|/det|>
the equation of the normal to the curve at the point where \(x = \frac{1}{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 631, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 104, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 144, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 76, 514, 102]]<|/det|>
Solve \(\sin x \cos x = \frac{1}{2} \tan x\) for \(0^{\circ} \leqslant x \leqslant 180^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 144, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 78, 181, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 75, 445, 101]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\sec \theta - \frac{\sin \theta}{\cot \theta} = \cos \theta .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 97]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 310, 180, 329]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 304, 787, 336]]<|/det|>
Hence solve \(\sec 3\theta - \frac{\sin 3\theta}{\cot 3\theta} = \frac{1}{2}\) for \(- \frac{2\pi}{3} \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{2\pi}{3}\) , where \(\theta\) is in radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 312, 920, 331]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
